Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Hierarchical fiber-reinforced soft-composites are composites made up of polymeric fibers (with specific material properties and hierarchical length-scales) embedded within a soft polymer matrix. Their emerging applications have highlighted the impending need to combine 3D printing (or additive manufacturing) technologies with the directed deposition of polymeric fiber networks. While the printing of multi-material polymer parts using droplet-deposition or melt-extrusion techniques is well-established, the 3D printing of hierarchical fiber-reinforced soft-composites is largely unproven. This award supports fundamental research directed towards developing 3D printing processes for these composites. The research findings will enable the development of a reliable and scalable 3D printing technology for such composites, leading to the creation of a new market-segment for 3D printers. It will also facilitate innovations in fields such as bio-inspired materials, embedded sensing, and 4D printing (3D printed products with shape-memory properties). These avenues collectively represent a multi-billion dollar world-wide market that affects key industries such as aerospace, healthcare, and defense. This award also supports educational outreach activities that will impact students in multiple institutions (including Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute and Hudson Valley community college) and the minority-serving middle/high-schools in the upstate New York area.

This research will investigate the fundamental manufacturing science and process-control problems unique to the 3D printing of hierarchical fiber-reinforced soft-composites. The PIs have recently invented a novel 3D printer that combines the conventional inkjet-based printing of ultraviolet curable polymers with the directed stamping of electrospun fiber networks. Using this 3D printing platform, the PIs will investigate the effect of key fiber and substrate properties on the fiber-transfer efficiencies and the physics of the fiber-droplet interactions encountered during the 3D printing process. On the experimental front, the research will focus on the manufacture of a diverse family of patterned fibers suitable for 3D printing, followed by process studies involving fiber-transfer efficiencies/material property characterization and high-speed imaging studies of fiber-droplet interactions. The modeling aspect of this research will focus on establishing novel control strategies tailored for 3D printing hierarchical fiber-reinforced soft-composites. The process studies will yield quantitative metrics that map the fiber-transfer efficiencies to critical process parameters such as stamping load, and fiber/substrate properties. These process maps will enable the selection of appropriate stamping load profiles while controlling the 3D printing process. The high-speed imaging study is expected to identify new droplet spreading regimes, droplet shapes and characteristic time-scales encountered during the 3D printing of hierarchical fiber-reinforced soft-composites.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

Hierarchical fiber-reinforced soft-composites (HFrSCs) are composites made up of polymeric fibers with specific material properties and hierarchical length-scales, embedded within another soft matrix. This research project has yielded a fundamental understanding of critical issues relevant to the nascent field of 3D printing HFrSCs. On the fibrous constructs front, we have developed a single, scalable manufacturing process for the continuous production of nanofiber-based ropes, cables, microscale wire coatings and multi-material fiber mats. This process innovation (cover image of J. of Applied Polymer Science V.133 (33)) allows for a greater diversity in the nature of the fibrous constructs used in HFrSC applications. On the 3D printing front, we have developed a novel electrospinning-based ?direct-write? system for printing laminated soft composites with aligned and random nanofiber mats. Tensile testing results showed that depending on the extent of alignment and the fiber content present in the 3D printed composite, it can have a 40%- 260% improvement in the elastic modulus over that of the base polymer. The composites also showed evidence of characteristic failure mechanisms seen in the domain of nanocomposite materials, namely, fiber-induced local plastic deformation (crazing), crack arrest and deflection, fiber strengthening, and fiber pullout.

 

In order to enable effective process planning of the 3D printing process, the droplet spreading characteristics were investigated using high-speed imaging. Our findings indicate that for a given fiber mat and ultraviolet curable matrix combination, the choice of the inline or orthogonal printing strategy (i.e., when the direction of the printing velocity either coincides or is perpendicular to the direction of fiber alignment) has implications for the overall printing time, fiber content, edge resolution and surface quality of the 3D printed soft composite part. Two mathematical models were also developed to aid the process planning efforts, including, (i) a cohesive-zone based finite element model aimed at improving the efficiency of the fiber transfer process; and (ii) an analytical model predicting the temporal shape-evolution of a droplet. The models are characterized by innovative extractions of the fiber-matrix cohesive properties and the use of free-energy barrier calculations, respectively.

Finally, the early-stage translation of our 3D printing protocols has been successfully demonstrated in three key biomedical applications including: (i) Morphologically relevant extracellular matrix (ECM) in-vitro models for cancer studies; (ii) Biologically-relevant complex 3D fiber-reinforced hydrogel structures; and (iii) Tailored bacterial cellulose structures. We have also shown the feasibility of using acoustic emission signals to monitor the gelation state of hydrogels during the bioprinting process.

Broader Impact

This research addressed fundamental manufacturing science problems that lie at the interface of 3D printing and composite manufacturing, both of which have been identified as technology areas of national importance. The findings will enable the effective integration of electrospinning-based, hierarchical fiber-writing technologies, with the ubiquitous Poly Jet 3D printing. This will not only create a new market-segment for 3D printers capable of printing soft composites, but will also enable innovations in 4D printing, bio-mimetic material design, and embedded sensing. Both these avenues collectively represent a multi-billion dollar world-wide market that affects key societal areas such as aerospace, healthcare, and defense.

On the education front, the research findings have been integrated as part of multiple graduate and undergraduate courses at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute, NY and also as part of the Global Initiative of Academic Networks course offering of the Govt. of India. The research findings were also integrated into an interactive, outreach to the middle/high-school students in upstate New York area.  In terms of human resource development, this project provided opportunities for the training and development of student researchers (1 MS, 4 PhD and 6 undergraduate) in the areas of advanced manufacturing and soft composite synthesis.  Some of US manufacturing companies employing these students include 3M, Ping and Medtronic. The project has resulted in a total of 9 peer-reviewed manuscripts (6 published and 3 in-preparation at the submission of this report)

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Intellectual Merit Hierarchical fiber-reinforced soft-composites (HFrSCs) are composites made up of polymeric fibers with specific material properties and hierarchical length-scales, embedded within another soft matrix. This research project has yielded a fundamental understanding of critical issues relevant to the nascent field of 3D printing HFrSCs. We have also shown the feasibility of using acoustic emission signals to monitor the gelation state of hydrogels during the bioprinting process.
